p: The RDF of Ca-H w and Ca-O w of montmorillonites with different charge density are shown in Figure 6. By studying the RDF of Ca-H w and Ca-O w in the interlayer of montmorillonites with different charge density, we can study the action of Ca 2+ and water molecules between the layers of montmorillonite; therefore, the mechanism of the influence of Ca 2+ on the distribution characteristics of water molecules can be further studied. It can be seen from Figure 6 that calcium ions are closely related to oxygen atoms in water molecules, the Ca 2+ and the oxygen atoms in the water molecules are more tightly packed together than that of hydrogens so Ca 2+ is more likely to have oxygen around than hydrogen in water molecules, and hydrated Ca 2+ are formed near the Si-O surface. Comparatively speaking, it can be seen that there is little difference in the RDF of Ca-H w and Ca-O w characteristics with the increases of layer charge density.
